Author: 10ren
Content:
By this definition of "shallow drivel", any summary is useless. They are providing an introduction - which is easier to read than the article. I think that's valuable. (BTW: I didn't realize you meant the online article - I thought you meant the actual research paper - my mistake).

The title is potentially misleading when taken out of context - but the text of the article doesn't distort the original article. It fact, it quotes heavily from it. So, possibly the title is disingenuous - but to say the entire article that 37Signals wrote is completely disingenuous is not accurate. At any rate, their title is substring of the linked article's title.

Judging an article by its headline and final line is similar to judging a book by its cover. It's possible to interpret the last line as you have - but only by ignoring the rest of the text. The line is a play on words "plan on improving" as an expression usually means just to decide to improve; but in the context of the article, it also means to have some strategy for improving. It's true that 37Signals advocates just moving in a direction; whereas the linked to article talks about written plans for gathering information. So I can sympathize with your point of view. There is still a lot of common ground between them, and both parties acknowledge the same reality, and the same kind of approach to a solution - but the details of the solutions differ.

For reference, here's the 37Signal article: http://www.37signals.com/svn/posts/1707-the-only-plan-is-to-...

EDIT reading the linked to article (I was relying on their academic paper before), I see what you mean in that they gloss over the details, which I'd summarise with this quote: I document all the assumptions that I'm making. And then I test these assumptions. I plan to test these assumptions at checkpoints. 37Signals is ignoring the details, but keeping the philosophy, which is If I'm likely to be wrong, then how do I plan in such a way that the cost of being wrong is as low as possible? Being extremely agile is a way to do that.

37Signals is not so much distorting the article, as summarizing its basic idea. The full article is linked to for further reading (as you have done).

BTW: I actually disagree with MacMillan's reverse income statement, for startups. Although it's sensible, it would have prevented Xerox from starting (IBM's consultants measured the price and potential market share, and concluded - accurately - that it wasn't worth pursuing given reality as it existed at that time). Of course, IBM was huge corporation even then, and had a different attitude to risk than startups do - and should have.

Anyway, thanks for explaining your point of view, it makes it possible to have an interesting discussion, especially with someone who disagrees with you - often the most fruitful kind.

Author: mdakin
Content:
This idea seems descriptive of someone with an entity (sometimes "fixed") theory of intelligence. I strongly encourage development of a incremental (sometimes "process", sometimes "growth") theory of intelligence instead. With the right growth-oriented mindset you will certainly not be the same person in ten years.

Read up on Carol Dweck's work. And Abraham Maslow's concept of self-actualization (not technically related to Dweck's work but seems somehow related to this discussion).

Author: riffic
Content: Twitter is not a public utility. People should really be looking into OpenMicroBlogging, and decentralization/federation with systems you set up and control, such as Laconica. This allows you to control the namespace, and downtime becomes your own problem.

Author: irrelative
Content:
I'm a little disappointed that Twitter has become the next big thing. Does it seem to everyone else that the next big thing has gotten easier and easier for the average programmer to make?

Google made sense as king of the hill, since it solved a relatively hard problem incredibly well. Then came Facebook, which solved a fairly easy problem, but scaled really well. Now Twitter has come along and solved a relatively simple problem, and they probably have the scaling issue figured out finally. Maybe I've just become jaded, but I thought we expected more from the next big thing both in terms of execution and difficulty.

Author: rmc00
Content: Most definitely yet. Twitter search has some real potential. It's growing rapidly as a place that people can search for quick reviews of restaurants, movies, etc.

Author: tptacek
Content:
Doesn't this paper basically say:

* Garbage collection is faster than manual frees when you provide processes with so much memory that collection happens so rarely that its cost is lost in the noise, and

* Garbage collection is faster than manual frees when you ignore all the constant factors in both collection and manually freeing, for instance the cost of taking page faults?

Author: tptacek
Content:
You're probably right, but the thing I learned from the first successful startup I was involved in that has stuck with me my whole career is the marketing power of customer service. It kills me when we can't make a client happy.

Maybe the trick is, pick good clients.

(The startup was an ISP, in 1996. Even in 1996, an indie ISP was hard to differentiate from the majors and incumbents. Mike and Tracy, the guys who ran the company, managed to build an unassailable reputation for customer service --- to this day, I don't understand how they did it, because I don't see how we did anything different from the other ISPs, other than to tell ourselves we had awesome customer service. But our ISP kicked ass up and down the block based almost entirely on that reputation. I'd love to get some of that mojo at Matasano.)

Author: zaius
Content: You can set which cores a process runs on in Windows. In task manager, right click on a task and click 'set affinity'. I'm sure there's a way to do it in linux too, but my linux box only has one core.

Author: ivank
Content: You can set the CPU affinity for specific processes on any modern operating system. Maybe you wanted to set this for every process that the application will launch? It's still possible, but even less user-friendly.

Author: netsp
Content:
Twitter's naming is very clever. I was talking to my girlfriend about birds the other day in the park. "I wonder what they're saying? 'I'm here.' 'I'm here?' 'Hungry' 'Scared' 'Happy?'" We decided they're just saying 'tweet tweet.'

A lot of the time that's what we do too. We communicate just for the sake of it. People talk to their babies. It's important to talk to your baby. It doesn't really matter what you say specifically, but you should say nice comforting things. Same with other people. "Hi, Howya goin." "nottaa-bother' 'tweet tweet.'

It still carries information.

Author: rmc00
Content: I found that I like hourly rates better than fixed prices. Fixed prices work great if you have a lot of experience on which you can base estimates. For someone who is an emerging developer, I would suggest starting out at a modest hourly rate. Once you have some credibility, you can bump up the hourly rate or start estimating using fixed price.

Author: wehriam
Content:
From anecdotal evidence, it's not unusual for iPhone devs to make $120 an hour or more. $60-$80 for a skilled developer with limited experience seems appropriate.

Don't be afraid to start at a high hourly rate, it almost always works out in your favor. Excuse the metaphor, but clients want to feel like they're getting a great deal on a Lexus rather than a satisfactory deal on a Hyundai, even if the price is the same. The key is elevating your perceived value. Talking clients through complex technical issues and possible solutions before negotiating often helps.

Don't bother with the freelancing sites, as rates are low. You'd be competing on price with overseas developers rather than playing to strengths like availability, perceived value of your formal education, and communication skills.
